conclusion: The problem involves determining the refractive index of a semi-cylindrical transparent object using Snell's law and geometry.
The semi-cylindrical object has a radius R, light enters along the axis OA, and reaches point C at a distance of (sqrt(3)/3)R from O.
At point C, no more light rays are emitted from the right side of the transparent object, indicating the light ray is at the critical angle for total internal reflection.
The distance from O to C is (sqrt(3)/3)R. Using the Pythagorean theorem, the angle theta that the light ray makes with the normal at point B can be calculated.
Using tan(theta) = (opposite)/(adjacent) = ((sqrt(3)/3)R)/R = sqrt(3)/3, the angle theta is determined to be pi/6.
The light ray enters the semi-cylindrical object at point A with an angle of incidence of 0 degrees and exits at point C with an angle of refraction theta = pi/6.
By Snell's law, n*sin(theta_i) = sin(theta_r). Since theta_i = 0 degrees, sin(theta_i) = 0, which is not possible, indicating the light is refracted and reflected back into the medium.
The critical angle theta_c is the angle of incidence at which the light is just at the point of total internal reflection. The refractive index n is given by n = 1/sin(theta_c).
Using the geometry of the situation, the angle BOC is determined to be pi/3, and the critical angle theta_c is pi/3.
The refractive index n is calculated as n = 1/sin(theta_c) = 1/sin(pi/3) = 1/(sqrt(3)/2) = 2/sqrt(3) = sqrt(3)/3.
